title: 108_hr4550
content: The Act is titled the "Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act" and requires visa waiver participants to electronically submit biographical information. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the United States. The system must provide an electronic response within 30 minutes regarding the alien's eligibility. The electronic system for visa waiver program participants must determine if an alien is eligible for admission as a nonimmigrant visitor. Carriers and corporations must electronically inquire about the alien's eligibility before embarkation, with a response provided within 90 seconds. The system for visa waiver program participants must be deployed promptly after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a fee to cover the full costs of operating the system. Consultation with a private sector group of experts in various fields is required during the system's development. SEC. 3. CHANGE TO REQUIREMENT FOR READERS AND SCANNERS AT PORTS OF ENTRY. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires the installation of equipment and software at all ports of entry into the United States for biometric comparison and authentication of visas, travel documents, and passports issued to aliens by October 26, 2005. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates the installation of equipment and software at all U.S. ports of entry for biometric authentication of visas, travel documents, and passports issued to aliens. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires technology standard implementation by 2005 for biometric authentication at U.S. ports of entry. Additionally, a limited good faith waiver is provided. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant up to 2 extensions for countries making progress towards meeting passport requirements, each extension lasting up to 6 months. The Secretary of Homeland Security considers factors like a country's effort to meet passport requirements by specific deadlines when granting extensions under the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act. In 2006, the Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, is required to issue initial and final reports on countries' progress in meeting specific requirements under the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends Section 303 of the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security".
